utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: It's almost eleven!

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: She needs a lot of sleep these days.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Please. Ms Bardach, I haven't seen her for a week.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: I'll see how she's feeling.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: You know what to do.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: All done?

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Yeah. I uh... scrubbed for 45 seconds, did the nails, all the way down to the elbows. The whole deal.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Are you sick?

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: No! No no no.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Cough? Sore throat?

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: No no no. I just... sometimes I sneeze when I look at lights. Always have.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: I'm sorry, you'd better--

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: I would never get her sick. Please.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: A mask.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Got me by the bouncer.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: She's crazy! She's let me out like 6 times in the last 2 months, every time is just to go to the hospital, I'm a prisoner!

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Aww, it's ok.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: It's ugly.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: No. I wasnâ€™t looking at the scar anyways.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: Take off your mask.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Uhh... if your mom comes in here...

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: Hey, give me a kiss or I'll kill you.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Your skin... are you ok?

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Melinda can you...hey what's wrong? What's wrong, is it your heart? What's wrong?! Mrs Bardach!!

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Melinda, I don't know how to use this, I've never used one of these before!

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: What did you do to her?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Cuddy called.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know. Saw the caller ID.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Young girl, anaphylactic shock.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You answered?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Turns out, that's what stops the ringing. It's a weird case. I thought you did the dishes last night. It was your day.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I did. Those are new. Midnight snack.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: For a midnight snack you made a pot roast. The same pot roast I made last night.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. Actually it was after midnight. Today is your day, right?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You want me out of here, I get it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No it's fine if you stay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The place I was going to move, the guy never called, otherwise I'd already be there.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I said it's fine if you stay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, that's why you're making me miserable.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maybe I just want to make sure you do your fair share around here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's weird about it? The girl with the allergies.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. She's immuno-compromised.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What? You asked me--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You knew that I was interested, that gives you a valuable bargaining chip. Could have had me doing dishes for a week.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ok. The allergic reaction happened while she was in a clean room.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why did she have a clean room in her home?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Heart transplant. The immune system's in the toilet, mommy builds her little angel a John Travolta quality bubble.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Six months after the transplant, she doesn't need to be confined to a clean room.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Six months without putting out, Dr Cuddy doesn't NEED to wear thong panties, but it's not our call.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I was wondering when you'd get around to my panties. She's had 4 days of work-ups. They've tested everyone who came anywhere near that room, everything in the room.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's like an Agatha Christie mystery.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Maybe it's not what was there; it's what she was doing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exercise allergy. Love it. What sort of exercise could a strapping young man and a nubile teenage nymphet possibly be--

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mom was in the room within seconds.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So the boyfriend brought in an allergen and is lying about it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Or the girl snuck out and she's lying about that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or the parents are lying about the room being clean.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: These are your big ideas? Somebody's lying?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hasn't let me down yet. Re-check mom, dad, the girl, the boy, the room and the home.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Any of you have a new soap? Detergent? Perfume?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And you haven't been outside recently?

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: How could I? I'm trapped up there.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: You're not trapped, it's just safe--

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: They won't even tell me the alarm code. Just tell her I can go back to school.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Until we've cleared this up

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: Fine. Find out what I'm allergic to and I'll stay away from it. Then I can go back to school. Right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's up to your parents, but err... medically, there's no reason...

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: Hah. Told you.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Could I speak to you outside for a second, please?

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: You know, this is hard enough without you--

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She asked my opinion.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: She is 16-yrs-old, lie to her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: When I was eight, my mom she... she hated--

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: I know, I... I need to loosen up. I'm overprotective, I saw Finding Nemo, I get it, I don't need another story.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You're not just being overprotective; you're one of the most overprotective parents I've ever seen!

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: She has the best private tutors. I let her friends visit, I'm not going to apologise.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just giving you my thoughts.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: She almost died 3 times during her childhood. Penicillin, bee stings, peanuts.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I've seen her file.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Six months ago, we leave her home alone for the first time on a weekend. She goes out, buys one chocolate chip cookie, peanut butter in the dough. She's forgotten her epi pen, she drives to the hospital, passes out, has an accident. Steering wheel crushed her chest. She ended up losing her heart. So when you say to me that I'm one of the most overprotective parents you've seen, please, please introduce me to the ones who were more protective. So that I can find out what they're doing right.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She's allergic to having a sucky social life.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Give the parents a break; they're just trying to keep her healthy. Everything in here is labelled hypo-allergenic.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Check it anyway. Cameron.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This place is cleaner than her hospital room.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No alarm on this window.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's a 20-foot drop.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You can get to the tree from here, there's some bark scraped off.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Sure, a heart transplant girl swung down there on a vine. Maybe she was hooking up with Tarzan and cheetah by the elephant graveyard.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Or, Jane stayed in the tree house, Tarzan came up.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Ok, erm... I spent most of the night, Friday, but if her mom finds out about that, she will totally freak.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You guys had sex?

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Yeah but... you know, I did everything I could to make sure she wouldn't get sick.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Latex allergy?

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: What do you mean, like a condom? We didn't...

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You had unsafe sex? The whole unsafe thing didn't tell you something?

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Yeah... but we didn't like... we didn't... plan on it, you know... just... I don't know, we're in love. We've been dating for 2 years.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Practically a lifetime. How about a semen allergy?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We're going to need a semen sample. You can use the bathroom over there.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Right, uh... how do I...

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Aim and shoot.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No thinking about Dr Cameron, we'll know.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We should tell her parents.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why stop there, call the cops.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Melinda's a minor.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And if we nip it in the bud here, teenagers will never again have sex. The parents will find out when they get the bill anyway.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Oh, so you're fine with them finding out as long as you don't have to tell them personally?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Pretty much.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Too bad it's not you giving the sample. We'd be done by now.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Test was negative. No semen allergy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Boyfriend sneaks in to get his freak on the night before the anaphylaxis, I don't buy that it's unrelated.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He loves her. Did everything he could to make sure she wouldn't get sick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's that mean?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Love is an emotion certain people experience, similar to happiness. No, maybe I should give a more relatable example.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh snap! What did he do to protect her, brillo-pad his privates?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I assume he washed and he...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh good work, assumptions are so much faster than actual questions.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You the boyfriend? Need to borrow you.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: What is going on?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don't worry. I'll return him in roughly the same condition.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you take anything to stay healthy? Something stronger than an apple a day?

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Is he ok?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's just tired. From being in a coma so long. What'd you take? Don't worry, he can keep a secret. Antibiotics? Penicillin? Any of those names ring a bell?

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Yeah, uh... my friend Elliot, his dad had like a whole bottle that he hadn't finished so I swiped it and took a bunch for like a week. There's no way I was going to risk breathing germs on Melinda.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is the one downside of teenage sex. You're idiots. You almost killed your girlfriend. She's allergic to penicillin.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: What do you think there was still some on my lips? I brushed my teeth!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Think lower, and more fun.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: I mean... it can... it can go through your stuff?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Totally, dude! There's this administrator here, whenever she gets sick she just gives me the prescription.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: But you know they tested Melinda, they said she wasn't allergic to my stuff.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, 4 days later. By that time the penicillin was crusting up a sock in the bottom of your hamper.

utterance.speaker: Dan
utterance.content: Do you have to tell her it was my fault?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Great part of being a grown-up, you never have to do anything.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: You're releasing her? What happened? What did you find out?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The test on your house ruled out any environmental allergens.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Yeah, but what caused this?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We believe it's highly unlikely that this set of circumstances will repeat itself.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: What set of circumstances?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's good news. She's healthy, but you might want to talk--

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Cameron!

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: I can't breathe!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Getting the epi.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No murmurs, no friction, no obstruction--

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Give her the shot!

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: What are you waiting for?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She's coughing up white sputum.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Crackling two thirds of the way up.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Look at her neck.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: She is vomiting, could you give her the shot?!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's not an allergy, it's her heart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's the good news, what's the bad news?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Congestive heart failure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is which?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Good news.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I don't know, it just sounded like you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: New puzzle piece, always good news. What's the bad news?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We've got 2 puzzle pieces from 2 different puzzles.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seems that way.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What if her anaphylaxis wasn't anaphylaxis. Toxicity from the anti-rejection meds could cause a seizure and then heart failure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And get cured by a mommy-wielded epi pen? It's anaphylaxis. What else?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What if there really are two puzzles?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You think she had 2 unrelated rare conditions in one week?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We explained the anaphylaxis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What do you mean 'we'? I did! Guess I thought I did, maybe I didn't. Still, it was all me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And heart problems aren't so rare for someone who's had a heart transplant. I say we assume House was right about the anaphylaxis--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It is tempting!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Heart failure could be either infection, coronary disease, or rejection.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, there's a reason they call it the WHITEboard. It's not my rule. What ties both of these conditions together?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ok, we can all stare at each other or we can investigate what caused the heart failure. Just the heart failure. You wanna give me that BLACK marker?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There's no fever, so it's probably not infection.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Or no fever because she's been on immuno-suppressants for about 6 months.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Let's do a CT, get a heart biopsy...

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Anything?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not yet. So I hear you don't want teenagers having sex. Teen suicide rate isn't high enough for you already?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I just think those two are brats. Girl undercuts her mother any chance she gets.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah it's the daughter's fault, has nothing to do with mom infantilising her.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Good point. Explains why parents who don't pay attention get such nice well-adjusted children.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What's this?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Think its vegetation?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, the kind made of muscle that opens your heart valves. It's nothing. She's clean.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's good news. You don't show any signs of coronary artery disease.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: So what's next?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, blood work to rule out infection, and then a heart surgical biopsy to rule out rejection.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: But you don't think you're going to rule out both things, do you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: I'm going to lose this heart, right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hopefully we'll find the problem and fix it. You'll keep your heart a long time.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: How long?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There could be drug breakthroughs that allow you to keep it for decades more.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: Yeah. That's the answer my cardiologist always gives me. I looked it up on the web. It's like... 5 or 10 years, right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That's about the average.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: That's why I need to have a life. Why can't you convince my mom to let me go back to school?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Melinda, you've got bigger worries right now than missing school. Until we figure out what's wrong with your heart, the safest place for you to be is right here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Where is... the hooker, I assume?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right up here, buddy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You said you'd hang the stethoscope if you were having sex.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn't say it had to be with another person. Can you think of anything that would tie together anaphylaxis and heart failure?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. I was waiting out there, for hours!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now I need a lot of foreplay, and then there's the cuddling afterwards. Any way that anaphylaxis isn't anaphylaxis even if it responds to epi?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. Well no wonder you were in the mood. This month's New Jersey journal of Cardiology.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Have you seen the centre fold? There's no WAY those valves are real! Any chance that the heart failure could be unrelated to--

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. If you need time alone to work, you just have to say so. You don't have to lie about it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lying's more fun.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Being lied to, not as much fun.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Please have an answer to this question: what's for dinner?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You STILL haven't done the dishes?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want one of these? I think I got a couple of blueberries... ohh... nope, sorry just one. Well don't look all weepy. If you've got a problem with me, deal with it! Short my sheets or something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Biopsy was negative for rejection.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Thank god.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: And what about the blood tests?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Showed no infection.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: So we still don't know what caused her heart failure.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Let's just be happy she doesn't need a new heart.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Mrs Bardach, it could have just been a one-time thing.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: So she has an allergic reaction and heart failure, and neither of them can be explained.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Are they doing anymore tests on her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: She's not here.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Notify local hospitals, cab companies, the state troopers and local cops. Any security officers off duty are back on duty.

utterance.speaker: Voice replies
utterance.content: We're on it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm going to need some pictures. And go through those drawers. And I want at least 2 people going over the surveillance tapes.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Will that work?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are those all her clothes?

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Uhh... yeah.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She's obviously still in the building. So where did she go, what does she want?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: To see her boyfriend?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She didn't take her phone.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She wants to be outside.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If youâ€™re trying to scare your parents, great job. Can we go back now?

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: I hate her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: When I was 8-yrs-old, I was sick. Well not really sick, but the point is my mom she could--

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: She was like this before. Home by nine every night, can't go out on the weekends, can't do sports, transplant just gave her what she always wanted.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Melinda, you had heart failure. This is kind of an insane time to be criticising your mom about being overprotective.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: I know. I mean this is what makes it even worse, all of her craziness is... it just... makes sense now.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Everything is going to be alright.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: I didn't even try to get outside. I was too scared.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Come on. Woah woah, Melinda, please walk back towards me.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Please?

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: It feels kind of weird.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's called steppage gait.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Is it serious?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not necessarily. Now stick your leg out, hold it up.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: She was under anesthesia for the biopsy, if she lost oxygen...

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: CT ruled out brain damage. Put your leg down. Relax.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Why is her leg twitching like that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Fasciculation.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Is that serious?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's paralysis. And it's ascending.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: She's going to lose the use of her legs?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: To start with.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's ascending fast; she can hardly extend her leg now.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: At this rate it'll be up to her lungs in a matter of days.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So... anaphylaxis, heart failure and paralysis. We couldn't put the first two together; I'm guessing we can't put all three together.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Tick paralysis? Could also explain the anaphylaxis, maybe even the--

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Penicillin allergy explains the allergic reaction much better.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Particularly because tick paralysis is usually accompanied by a tick. We did two comprehensive physicals looking for insect bites.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can we put any two of those together?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How about we stipulate? You argue that there must be something to connect all 3 symptoms, you mocked us for not figuring it out and finally you let us discuss the paralysis on its own because it's what's gonna to kill her. Now it's ascending, MRI's are clean so rule out stroke or aneurysm.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: ALS? MS?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Progression's too quick.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Spinal lesion from leukaemia?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Too slow. It's most likely Guillain-Barre.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She's immuno-suppressed. What about botulism?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not unless she's been walking around on her hands the last couple of days. Botulism paralysis is descending, not ascending.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Could be a virus. West Nile, even Polio with her immune system shot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get an LP. And do PCRs for the viruses. And get an EMG to check for Guillain-Barre. Foreman's right, we've got to find out why she's paralysed. But not before staring at me dumbly for a few seconds.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We ran more tests on your daughter. We took a lumbar puncture; got some spinal fluid and we brought it to the lab to look for infections that could be affecting her brain. We also did an EMG to check how her muscles and nerves are responding to electrical impulses. Unfortunately, her muscles are showing increased weakness above the knee.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: You mean she's getting worse?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The LP and PCRs ruled out Polio and West Nile. We think its Guillain-Barre. Her body's immune response goes haywire, starts attacking the peripheral nerves. It causes muscle weakness and paralysis.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: How bad is it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's serious, but Guillain-Barre usually responds very well to plasmapheresis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You see the plasma, the clear liquid part of her blood, contains most of the antibodies which are overreacting and attacking her nervous system. The machine spins her blood in a centrifuge and separates parts of the blood based on weight. White blood cells are the heaviest, then the red cells, then platelets and plasma. We discard the stuff that's causing all the trouble and return the good blood cells back to her body in a replacement fluid. If it works, we'll see results in a couple of days.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You didn't get any messages for me last week, did you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That's funny, guy finally called back. Place I lost? Said he left 3 voicemails.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gotta pee.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Which I never got. If that wasn't clear.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He must be lying. You wouldn't want to live with a liar.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You erased my messages?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yup! Decided I wanted you to stay. Told you that didn't I?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're... miserable, and you're lonely, and you're going to trap me here to keep me every bit as miserable and lonely too

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, and you're happy happy happy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ok, hey, I'm obviously going through a rough patch here. Your wife leaves, tends to bum somebody out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you know where my pee went?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're missing some?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope, came out of me and went right into the toilet. Now why would that be?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're William Tell, you could pick an apple off someone's head?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, it's because there was no clear plastic wrap over the toilet. The stuff's in the kitchen, you have plenty of time. All that was missing was the WILL.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: This isn't a college dorm!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It could be.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We're not 18!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what? What did I do to you? I scammed you into doing the dishes, made you sit on the steps. I didn't kill your puppy. I did not make you miserable.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, so this is therapy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No... just makes me smile.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: All right, I'm finding a new place tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, but not tonight.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well I figure you wanna shave my eyebrows while I'm asleep I wouldn't want to deprive you of that last smile.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're not going anywhere. You're going to sit on my couch, and depress us both because you just can't admit that it's over with your wife.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That's right, I'm here on vacation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Have you gotten a lawyer yet?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That's... that's... not...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You even called one? As long as you're here, it's just a fight. As soon as you get a place, then it's a divorce. Everything sucks. Might as well find something to smile about.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Reflexes are marginally weaker.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Her paralysis is getting worse?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sometimes it takes a few treatments for the plasmapheresis to work.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: Why do these things keep happening to me?

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Dan's back.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Baby did you hear that? Dan's here.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: I don't want to see him.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: I'll tell him to come back later.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: No! Mommy, stay here, please.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She ok?

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Just sleeping.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm sure she's exhausted. Mood swings are common with the anti-rejection meds.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: No, she's had mood swings. This isn't it; this is... she's given up. I know you think I'm... this isn't what I wanted. She's always fought with me, ever since she was a baby she was so damn stubborn. But I never wanted her like this. I just wanted her safe.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Doctor. Doctor!

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: She can't breathe, she couldn't even get a whole sentence out.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She's losing accessory muscles.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: O2 stat's down to 90, lungs clear? Does your tongue feel swollen?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No hives.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It's not an allergy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her lips are cyanotic, we've got to intubate.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Pushing lorazepam.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She's not getting enough oxygen, we've got to assist her breathing.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: What was that? Was that a reaction to the treatment?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's the paralysis. It's reached her lungs.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Melinda's dying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We're all dying. How fast?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Too fast for Guillain-Barre.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Cuddy wants to get her an MRI to rule out a spinal lesion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cuddy? What's she doing on this?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The family lost confidence in us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't blame them. I'll be right in.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's like she got poisoned with a nerve agent.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Glue inhalation. Would explain why she hasn't admitted it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tox screen was clear for pot. Middle class heart transplant patient's going to huff glue?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Pesticides?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This time of the year they're not spraying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This girl's tough. She gets what she wants. She's deprived of human contact; she gets herself a back door man. Or in her case, a side window boy. What else has she been deprived of?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She's on a special diet because of her allergies.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The boyfriend brings the hot beef, he also brings a side dish. Botulism.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This paralysis is ascending, remember?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not if the heart problem was really a paralytic problem.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why would she admit the sex and not the food?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She didn't admit anything. He admitted the sex and we didn't ask him about food.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get me a rat.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You have a rat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What? We're not going to kill Steve! Only way to confirm this, we inject a rat with her blood, and wait for it to get all botulistic on your ass. In the meantime I'm going downstairs to browbeat the scared dying teenage girl until she... breaks down like a scared dying teenage girl.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're up early.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Cuddy needed a consult.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We're checking for spinal lesions from leukaemia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I know. Fits perfectly. Unless this is the patient with the anaphylaxis, the heart failure, and the paralysis. In which case you're wasting your time.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: We wanted a second opinion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Second? We've given you at least 8. Ok, well then here is 9. Botulism. Listen to me, have you eaten anything abnormal? Any canned foods?

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sure? Lying to your parents is usually the right thing to do, but there is an impending death exception.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Don't talk to her like that!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're right, she never lies. I was being rude. When your boyfriend snuck in on Friday night - surprise! - perhaps he got you some sexy little treats, huh? Some honey or some edible underwears, massage oils, come on, anything.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: We didn't--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, we know about the sex. Turns out that Danny's little Danny is full of penicillin and that's what caused your anaphylactic shock.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: What? You didn't tell us that!

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: No! It was clindamycin, what I use.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He said he was on penicillin.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: I saw the bottle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's a non-penicillin antibiotic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If the antibiotics didn't cause the anaphylaxis...

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's still on the table.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Everything's connected.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What did we discuss? What was the differential?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cameron said... When Dan came to your house that night, did he go through any tall grass?

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: Climbed a fence.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your daughter had 2 visitors on Friday night. One of them is still in the room. She has tick paralysis. Dan tracked a tick on to his jeans, which wouldn't be a problem but being a teenager, Dan couldn't keep his tick in his pants.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We already checked her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now I'm checking her.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Tick bites don't ordinarily cause anaphylactic shock.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This girl's allergies are not ordinary.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, get out of here, we have to re-intubate her, and get her into the MRI.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Time course is perfect. Bite itself sets off an allergic reaction, venom takes 4 days to kick in, heart's vulnerable, hits that first. Then a day later, sets off the ascending paralysis.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Except that ticks aren't usually invisible.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They are until you find them! oh no, that's dandruff. Okay well that wasn't nearly as dramatic as I'd hoped. It just means that next time it'll be even better.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: What's happening?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's the tick venom ascending.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Either that or you stressed her into heart failure. BP's dropping. Heart rate 47.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm administering atropine.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She's going to need a trans-venous pacing wire. Ok, magical tick hunt is over! Only real doctor stuff now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's just going to get worse. Ticks produce more toxins the longer they feed. She's going to be dead in an hour, even if you pump her heart full of jet fuel. Unless you let me find the tick.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Could he be right?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The only thing I know for sure is that your daughter's heart won't last another 20 minutes without treatment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, just need one final instruction, when I find the tick on the autopsy, do you want to know? I'm thinking not, probably will make coping easier.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Stop talking to them! Page Borsisky in Cardiology and get her team down here, stat. Get them out of here, get House out of here too. Dr Wilson, I could use your help.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well I don't know if the dopamine's enough. She may need an inamrinone lactate.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Why? What's that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She doesn't--

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She might need stronger pressers and they don't have any in radiology.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Inamrinone can cause arrhythmia and thrombocytopenia.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Not inamrinone could cause death. Death's worse. We have to get her up to the ICU.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, a little crowded in here.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, get out of the elevator.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're welcome to wait for the next one.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You got her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Got her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well as long as we're stuck here, this might be a good time to look for that tick.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Turn the elevator back on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just be a minute, honey.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Atropine's wearing off.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Inject her again.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That's just temporary.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Temporary's fine, we're not hanging wallpaper.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We've got to get her upstairs and put her on norepiniphrine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It wasn't penicillin. You still think the symptoms are unconnected?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We've got to take care of her heart--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You wake up in the morning, your paint's peeling, your curtains are gone, and the water's boiling. Which problem do you deal with first?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: None of them! The building's on fire! We treat her symptoms, she dies, we find the cause, she lives. That tick is an IV drip of poison, we unhook it, she'll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This is my last atropine. Buys us about 3 minutes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Letâ€™s get her gown up.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her heart rate falls below 35; we're getting her to the ICU. Not going to let her die in this elevator.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Where are they?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Get maintenance up here right away.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ear canal's clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Left foot's clean.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If it's not here, we've only got... heart rate's 46.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's here. Looks like a mole or a freckle, something we missed. Check the armpits.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr Foreman's an excellent doctor; he'll be able to handle it.

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: Yeah? You know that from experience? You lose a lot of patient's on elevators?

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: The maintenance guy said that it didn't just stop on its own, that they hit the emergency stop button.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm sure he must be mistaken.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Perinuem.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We checked it. If we get her upstairs--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maxilla.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Checked. Down to 38. We don't have a lot of time, we've got to--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eyebrows, eardrums, pubic hair.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Checked, checked, checked. We checked everywhere. It's not-- 35, we've got to get her to the ICU.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We haven't found the tick yet.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We already kidnapped her, you want to add murder!? We've looked over every inch of skin on her body, House. It's over.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, is that the first time you had sex? With all the other stuff going on down there she might not have realised...

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh!

utterance.speaker: Lewis
utterance.content: You sick, miserable--

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What are you doing?!

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: Oh my god!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wait!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See? I told you it'd be even more dramatic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Push norepiniphrine, get her heart back to normal. She'll be completely cured by tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Foreman, let's get her into the ICU.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Inamrinone was a stupid idea. Unless you wanted me to get that girl in the elevator.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, I wouldn't do that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wouldn't respect you if you did.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wow. Looks like somebody filed halfway through your cane while you were sleeping.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Reflexes back to normal. Heart's looking good too. I'll send in the nurse, we'll get you transferred out of ICU and you'll be discharged in the morning.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: Thank god, I just want to get home.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: And back to school on Monday.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: I'm not ready.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: You're ready.

utterance.speaker: Melinda
utterance.content: I'm sick, mom.

utterance.speaker: Barbara
utterance.content: You're not sick. You're going to go to class. And you're going to see your friends, and your boyfriend.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I called a divorce lawyer today.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does that mean you're leaving?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: At some point. You might not want to sit exactly there.
